description: Late Middle English, from Old French bastir (“build, construct, sew up (a garment)”).

verbs.description: baste (third-person singular simple present bastes, present participle basting, simple past and past participle basted)

entries.meaning: To sew with long or loose stitches, as for temporary use, or in preparation for gathering the fabric.

description: Middle English basten, of uncertain etymon, possibly from Old French basser (“moisten, soak”), from bacin (“basin”).

entries.meaning: A basting; a sprinkling of drippings etc. in cooking.
examples: "Just like a leg of mutton being roasted before a slow fire without any one to give it a baste," groaned the old man.

verbs.description: baste (third-person singular simple present bastes, present participle basting, simple past and past participle basted)

entries.meaning: To sprinkle flour and salt and drip butter or fat on, as on meat in roasting.

description:
Perhaps from the cookery sense of baste or from some Scandinavian etymon. Compare Old Norse beysta (“to beat, thresh”) (whence
Danish børste (“to beat up”)). Compare also
Swedish basa (“to beat with a rod, to flog”) and
Swedish bösta (“to thump”).
Might be related to French bâton (“stick”) (formerly baston); English baton comes from bâton; see also French bastonnade (“the act of beating with a stick”).

verbs.description: baste (third-person singular simple present bastes, present participle basting, simple past and past participle basted)

entries.meaning: (archaic, slang) To beat with a stick; to cudgel.
examples: One man was basted by the keeper for carrying some people over on his back through the waters.
